Title.evidence: High-Sensitivity Cardiac Troponin T in Detecting Perioperative Myocardial Infarction: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Conducted as an ancillary study within the Vitamins in Nitrous Oxide trial

Participants.evidence: 605 patients who had baseline and at least one postoperative hscTnT measurement. The study setting was a surgical environment.

Intervention.evidence: assessed the utility of a high-sensitivity cardiac troponin T (hscTnT) assay versus contemporary cardiac troponin I (cTnI)

Objective.evidence: This study assessed the utility of a high-sensitivity cardiac troponin T (hscTnT) assay versus contemporary cardiac troponin I (cTnI) in identifying perioperative myocardial infarction (MI) following non-cardiac surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of myocardial injury and MI

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not detailed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding of outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians was not specified.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 605 patients, 70 (12%) exhibited ECG changes indicative of myocardial ischemia.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Using contemporary cTnI, 82 patients (14%) were diagnosed with myocardial injury, with 31 (5.1%) confirmed as MI. The hscTnT assay identified 67 patients (11%) with MI, representing a twofold increase in detection.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding information were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding information were not provided.
